events.summary: Juan prepares to leave Jaen for Malaga to take personal command against Granada raiders plaguing supply lines. He calls Isabel to say goodbye. The couple shares an emotional farewell scene: Isabel, six months pregnant, expresses her fear and love. They pray together at the small Portuguese-style chapel in their chambers, Juan asking God to protect Isabel as she becomes a mother. Isabel promises to pray every day until his return.

CHAPTER 23: THE COUNTER-RAID

Date: September 14, 1431
Location: Royal Apartments, Jaén

The afternoon sun slants through the narrow windows of your chambers as you finish checking your armor and weapons. Your squires have already loaded your traveling chests—lighter kit than usual for mobile operations against raiders. The expedition to Málaga will be swift; you plan to join the forces there, assess the situation firsthand, and personally take command of operations to crush the harassment that has plagued your supply lines for weeks.

A soft knock at the door, then it opens. Isabel enters, moving with the careful grace of a woman six months pregnant. Her belly is unmistakably rounded now beneath her deep blue gown, and her face—while still plain by courtly standards—carries a luminous quality you've come to recognize. She's frightened, trying not to show it.

Dona Beatriz follows a respectful distance behind, then quietly withdraws, closing the door to give you privacy.

Isabel stops a few paces away, hands clasped over her belly. Her eyes search your face. When she speaks, her voice is steady despite the fear behind it: "Your Majesty asked for me. I... I wanted to see you before you left."

Isabel. I will leave for the war again and we will not see each other again for a few months I think. I will miss you terribly, love. Especially now that you are pregnant.


I dont want to say goodbye at all.

Given Juan's vulnerable statement here - expressing he'll miss her terribly, doesn't want to say goodbye - Isabel would likely:
1. Be deeply moved by his honesty
2. Share her own fears
3. Try to be brave for him but struggle
4. Express her love
5. Worry about him

Isabel's composure wavers. Her eyes glisten, and she takes a step closer, then another, until she's standing before you. One hand reaches out to touch your arm—a gesture that would have been unthinkable in the dutiful bride who arrived from Portugal nine months ago.

"I don't want you to go," she whispers, and the admission costs her something. Her voice breaks slightly. "I know that's selfish. I know the kingdom needs you, and the crusade, and... I know all of that. But Juan—"

She looks up at you, tears now spilling down her cheeks. "Every night since you left for the east, I pray the rosary until my hands hurt. I pray that God will protect you, that you'll come back whole. And every time a messenger arrives, my heart stops until I know it's not... not bad news." Her hand moves from your arm to rest over her rounded belly. "The baby moves now. Every day. And I think about how I want them to know their father. How I want you to hold them."

She draws a shaking breath. "I'm frightened, my lord. Frightened that something will happen to you and I'll..." She can't finish the sentence. Instead, she steps fully into your arms, burying her face against your chest, her pregnant belly pressed between you both.

"I'll miss you every moment you're gone," she says into your tunic, voice muffled. "Please come back to us."

I hold her tight.


I will Isabel. I promise. Im sure of it.


Will you pray with me for a moment, and will you pray for me until I get back?

Isabel pulls back just enough to look up at you, wiping at her tears with one hand. She nods fiercely. "Yes. Yes, of course."

She takes your hand and leads you to the small Portuguese-style chapel corner you'd had installed in these chambers—the carved wooden prie-dieu, the icon of the Virgin Mary you'd given her in August, fresh flowers in a simple clay vase. The Virgin figure has pride of place on a small shelf, clearly well-used; the wood is smooth from Isabel's hands.

She kneels carefully, one hand steadying herself as she lowers her pregnant body, then reaches for your hand as you kneel beside her. Her fingers lace through yours, gripping tightly.

"Holy Mother," Isabel begins in Portuguese, her voice soft but steady now that she's in this familiar territory, "watch over my husband. Keep him safe from harm. Guide his decisions, protect him in battle, bring him home to us whole and well."

She pauses, then switches to Castilian—a deliberate choice, speaking your language for this. "Blessed Virgin, you know what it means to fear for someone you love. You stood at the foot of the Cross. Please... please don't let me know that pain. Let our child know their father. Let me have more years with him. Keep him safe."

Her grip on your hand tightens almost painfully. "I will pray every day," she whispers. "Every single day until you return. Morning prayers, evening prayers, the rosary. I'll light candles. I'll make offerings. Whatever God asks of me, I'll do it, if He'll only bring you back."

She falls silent then, head bowed, waiting for you to pray with her.

O merciful father in heaven. Grant us strength in the days and weeks ahead. We all have our role to play. Protect Isabel as she takes on a role of mother. Be with her when she feels alone and lost. And lord, you know the secrets of our hearst. You know that we want nothing more than to serve you together. May we wake up in the morning together so we may sing your praises forever.


Amen.

Isabel would be deeply moved by this. Juan is:
1. Thinking of her needs (protection, comfort when alone)
2. Acknowledging her new role as mother
3. Expressing their shared faith and partnership
4. Implicitly promising to return by asking God to let them wake together

This is exactly the kind of prayer that would resonate with Isabel - personal, specific, acknowledging both their individual struggles and their partnership. It shows Juan has learned how to reach her heart through their shared faith.

I should show Isabel's emotional response, then have them conclude this farewell scene. She would be crying again, but comforted. This is a deeply intimate moment between them.

I need to stop after their farewell is complete and wait for the player to indicate what Juan does next (leaves immediately, says something else, etc.).

"Amen," Isabel whispers, her voice thick with tears.

For a long moment she stays kneeling beside you, head bowed, your hands still clasped together. Her shoulders shake with silent weeping. Then she turns toward you, still on her knees, and throws her arms around your neck.

"Thank you," she breathes against your ear. "Thank you for understanding. For knowing what I needed to hear." She pulls back enough to look at you, tears streaming down her face, but there's something like peace mixed with the sorrow now. "You're not just leaving me for the war. You're trusting God to keep us both safe until we're together again. That's... that's what I needed."

She kisses you then—desperate, clinging, trying to memorize the moment. When she finally pulls away, she touches your face with both hands, studying you as if to commit every detail to memory.

"I'll be here when you return," she says, steadying her voice with visible effort. "I'll be praying every day. And..." She places your hand on her swollen belly, pressing it there. "We'll both be waiting for you. Your son or daughter will know their father's voice the moment they hear it, because I'll tell them stories about you every day."

She takes a shaking breath, then rises awkwardly to her feet. You stand and help steady her.

"Go," she says, though it clearly costs her everything to say it. "Go and do what you must. Win your battles. End this war. Come home to us."

She's trying so hard to be brave, to be the queen she's learned to become. But her eyes plead with you not to leave even as her words release you.

The Ambush on the Road to Málaga

Day 3 - September 17, 1431
Afternoon - Hill Country South of Jaén

The afternoon heat presses down as your column winds through the broken terrain forty miles south of Jaén. Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles rides beside you, fifty royal guards spread in protective formation—twenty ahead, twenty behind, ten flanking. Good discipline. Professional spacing.

The arrow takes the lead scout in the throat.

He topples from his saddle without a sound. Then the hillside erupts—thirty, forty Granada light cavalry pouring from concealed positions in the scrub-covered ravines on both sides of the road. They're already at full gallop, screaming their war cries, lances leveled.

"AMBUSH! CLOSE ON THE KING!" Fernán's roar cuts through the chaos. The guards react instantly, spurring toward you, but the raiders are fast—terrifyingly fast. They hit your forward element before half your men can respond.

Steel rings on steel. A Castilian guardsman goes down with a lance through his ribs. Another's horse collapses, arrows bristling from its neck. The raiders aren't trying to hold ground—they wheel and strike, wheel and strike, flowing like water around your formation's attempts to consolidate.

"They're trying to separate you from the column!" Fernán shouts, his sword already red. "We need to—"

A cluster of raiders surges toward your position specifically. Six men, well-mounted, lances aimed directly at you. Your guards intercept them—Fernán personally cuts down the lead rider—but in the swirling melee, you're being pushed away from the main body of your escort. More of your men are falling. You can see at least eight Castilians down already, dead or dying.

The raiders break off as suddenly as they struck, galloping back into the hills. But they don't flee far—you can see them regrouping on the ridgelines, just out of bowshot, watching. Counting your numbers. Planning the next strike.

Fernán pulls his horse alongside yours, breathing hard. Blood runs from a cut on his arm. "Your Majesty, we've lost nine men. Maybe ten if Pedro doesn't stop bleeding. They'll hit us again—this is how they fight. Wear us down attack by attack." He gestures at the terrain ahead—three more miles of broken country before the road descends to more open ground. "We can try to push through fast and hope they don't hit us again. Or we can turtle up, move slow and defensive. Or..." He glances back north. "We could retreat to the last town, get reinforcements."

On the ridgeline, the raiders sit their horses, waiting. You can see more movement in the ravines—possibly more groups positioning for another ambush if you continue forward.

Captain Fernán looks at you, waiting for orders.
Can we charge at them?

Juan is asking if they can charge at the raiders on the ridgeline. This is a tactical question I should answer as the GM based on military reality and Captain Fernán's expertise.

Key factors:
1. The raiders are Granada light cavalry - their entire tactical doctrine is built around mobility and hit-and-run
2. They're on ridgelines, higher ground
3. They're specifically designed to bait charges and then flee, leading pursuers into worse terrain or splitting forces
4. Juan's force is royal guards - heavier cavalry, good fighters but not as mobile as light cavalry
5. The terrain is broken hill country with ravines - terrible for charging
6. The raiders have already shown they know this terrain intimately
7. Splitting the force to chase them would leave Juan vulnerable to other raider groups

Fernán would absolutely advise against this - it's exactly what the raiders want. But I should present it as his expert opinion and let Juan decide.

Fernán follows your gaze to the raiders on the ridgeline, then shakes his head sharply. "Your Majesty, that's exactly what they want us to do."

He points at the terrain. "Look at the ground between us and them. Broken, rocky, full of gullies and ravines we can't see from here. They're light cavalry on horses bred for this country—we're heavy horse built for shock charges on flat ground. We'd be climbing toward them at half speed while they pepper us with arrows, then the moment we got close, they'd scatter in six directions through terrain they know like their own homes."

He gestures to the other groups of raiders visible on different hilltops. "And the second we committed to chasing that group, these others would hit our rear. Or worse—they'd circle around and hit wherever you're not. That's their entire way of fighting, Majesty. Make you chase, split your forces, bleed you piece by piece."

One of your guards rides up. "Captain, Pedro's dead. That makes ten." His voice is tight with anger. "And the bastards are just sitting up there watching us."

Fernán's jaw clenches. You can see he wants to kill them as badly as his men do. But he turns back to you. "I've fought these raiders before, Your Majesty. Never, ever chase them into broken ground. That's how Infante Enrique lost forty men in his ambush—they baited his cavalry into a pursuit and had three more groups waiting."

On the ridge, one of the raiders raises his lance mockingly, as if inviting exactly what you suggested.

"We need a decision, Your Majesty," Fernán says quietly. "Push through fast and accept they might hit us again? Move slow and defensive? Pull back north? But charging up those hills..." He shakes his head. "That's suicide, and they know it."

What are your orders?
Our fight starts here. If we retreat, can we call up more reinforcements?

Juan is asking a practical question about whether retreat would allow him to gather reinforcements. This is a reasonable strategic consideration. Fernán would have knowledge about what forces might be available in the area and how long it would take to gather them.

- There might be small garrisons in towns, or patrols in the area

He pauses, calculating. "From there, we could send riders to Jaén for proper reinforcements. Don Álvaro de Estúñiga could send a hundred cavalry, maybe two hundred. But that's a full day's ride each way—so two days minimum before they arrive. Maybe three to organize properly."

One of his sergeants speaks up. "By which time these goat-fuckers will be long gone, Captain. They're not going to sit around waiting for us to come back with an army."

Fernán nods grimly. "He's right, Your Majesty. If we retreat, we save our remaining men and get you safely back. But these specific raiders will vanish into the hills. We'd have to start the whole hunt over again." He gestures at the watching horsemen. "Right now, we know where they are. We're wounded, but they think they have us."

He meets your eyes. "If our fight truly starts here, then we push through. Take more casualties, probably, but reach Málaga with most of your escort intact. From there, you'll have twelve thousand men to hunt these bastards properly."

Another option crosses his face. "Or... Your Majesty, you could retreat to Alcaudete with ten guards while the rest of us push through. Get you safe, then—"

"No." The sergeant cuts him off flatly. "We don't split the king from his escort in raider country. That's how kings get captured."

On the ridge, the raiders haven't moved. Still watching. Still waiting for your decision.
When we push through, what will happen? How can we best defend ourselves?

This is good military advice from an experienced captain who has fought raiders before. I should have Fernán lay out the tactical situation clearly.

Fernán leans forward in his saddle, studying the terrain ahead. "If we push through, they'll hit us at least once more, maybe twice. They'll wait for another choke point—narrow section of road, a ford, anywhere our formation has to compress. Then strike fast, kill a few men, and break off before we can counter."

He points to your remaining guards. "We have forty-one men left. Here's how we defend against it:"

"Tight formation—no one more than two horse-lengths from the next man. When they charge, we don't chase. We receive their attack, kill who we can, let them break off. They want to pull us apart; we stay together like a fist."

"You in the center—ten best men around you at all times, shields ready. When arrows fly or lances come, they protect you first. Everyone else fights outward from that core."

"Fast but not reckless—we push hard through the dangerous ground, don't give them time to set perfect ambushes. But we don't gallop blind into another trap either. Scouts ahead but not too far."

"No heroics—if someone falls, we don't stop to retrieve bodies. Sounds harsh, but that's what gets everyone killed. We push through to open ground, regroup there."

He looks at you directly. "Realistically, Your Majesty? We'll lose another five to ten men getting through these three miles. Maybe more if we're unlucky. But the core around you should hold, and once we reach open country, they can't touch us—their horses won't catch ours in a straight run."

The sergeant adds quietly: "And every man here knew the risks when we rode south, Your Majesty. We'll get you through."

Fernán waits for your decision. Push through with these tactics? Or choose differently?

Men, God is testing our resolve right now. But I know we will preservere. We must preservere.

The Push Through

Your words ripple through the remaining guards. Spines straighten. Hands tighten on weapons. Captain Fernán nods once, then bellows: "You heard His Majesty! Tight formation! Move out!"

The column reforms with professional speed—ten guards in a tight ring around you, the rest forming a compact mass fore and aft. No gaps. No stragglers. When a young guardsman's horse limps badly from an arrow wound, another man pulls him up behind his saddle without breaking stride. The formation moves as one.

The raiders see it. On the ridgeline, their leader gestures sharply. They begin shadowing your column, looking for an opening that never comes.

At the first choke point—a narrow defile where the road cuts between two rocky outcrops—arrows hiss down from above. One catches a guard in the shoulder, but he stays in saddle, shield raised. The formation doesn't slow, doesn't waver. The raiders start to close for a charge, but Fernán roars "HOLD FORMATION!" and your men stay locked together like a moving fortress. The raiders wheel away, frustrated.

Two miles. The raiders try again at a ford crossing, splashing in from both flanks. This time they commit harder—eight men with lances driving at your left flank. Steel clashes. One of your guards goes down, trampled in the shallow water, but the man beside him immediately closes the gap. The raiders break off as your formation simply absorbs the attack and keeps moving, implacable as the tide.

One mile. The raiders make a final attempt, trying to bait your rearguard into pursuit by riding close and hurling insults. Not one man breaks ranks. The discipline holds absolutely.

Then the terrain opens. The broken hills give way to rolling grassland, and suddenly there's nowhere for light cavalry to hide, nowhere to ambush from. Your column emerges onto the open road to Málaga.

Behind you, the raiders pull up on the last ridgeline, watching. They don't follow into the open country. One by one, they turn their horses and disappear back into the hills.

Captain Fernán rides up beside you, breathing hard. Blood stains his surcoat but he's grinning fiercely. "Forty men remaining, Your Majesty. Two wounded but riding. The bastards couldn't break us." He looks back at his guards with obvious pride. "Your Majesty's words held them together. They fought like they were worth twice their number."

The road to Málaga stretches ahead, clear and safe in the afternoon sun. Two more days of easy riding.

Arrival at Málaga

Day 5 - September 19, 1431
Afternoon - Málaga

The final two days pass without incident. Open roads, good weather, fresh horses requisitioned at towns along the way. Captain Fernán keeps the formation tight anyway—no one taking chances after the ambush—but the raiders don't reappear.

Málaga rises from the coastal plain ahead, its white walls gleaming in the Mediterranean sun. The Moorish architecture still dominates the skyline despite three months of Castilian occupation—minarets and domes alongside the new Christian banners flying from the Alcazaba fortress. The harbor bristles with ships: Castilian galleys, Portuguese carracks, supply vessels. The smell of salt air and fish markets carries on the breeze.

Your approach is spotted. Trumpets sound from the walls. By the time you reach the gates, a reception party has assembled—Master of Santiago Don Luis de Guzmán at its head, surrounded by his officers and household knights.

Don Luis dismounts and kneels as you enter. "Your Majesty. We received word you were coming, but not that you'd been engaged on the road." His eyes take in your reduced escort, the bloodstains, the exhausted horses. "I see the raiders found you as well."

War Council at Málaga

Evening - September 19, 1431
Alcazaba Fortress, Málaga

The council chamber overlooks the harbor, Mediterranean sunset painting the water gold and crimson. Maps spread across a heavy oak table—the coastal region from Málaga to Gibraltar, the interior hills, supply routes marked in red ink with crosses noting ambush sites. Too many crosses.

Master of Santiago Don Luis de Guzmán stands at the head of the table. Flanking him: Master Gunner Pietro Calabrese, still dust-stained from recent siege work; Don Rodrigo de Perea, the scout commander who survived Infante Enrique's disastrous ambush last month; Admiral Don Fadrique Enríquez, commanding the naval elements; and half a dozen garrison commanders from captured fortresses.

Don Luis begins without preamble. "Your Majesty, since June we've captured six coastal fortresses—Marbella, Estepona, Casares, Manilva, and two smaller positions. The Master Gunner's artillery has been devastating. We control forty miles of coastline." He taps the map. "But holding these positions bleeds us constantly."

Don Rodrigo leans forward, voice bitter. "The raiders, Your Majesty. Granada has fifteen hundred to two thousand light cavalry deployed in bands of fifty to three hundred. They've abandoned trying to stop our sieges. Instead, they hit supply convoys, isolated garrisons, foraging parties, messenger patrols. We've lost over two hundred men since July—not in glorious battle, but murdered on the roads in ones and twos."

Pietro Calabrese adds in his Italian-accented Castilian: "Every convoy needs hundred men escort now, Majesty. Still they hit us. My bombards sit idle for days waiting for enough powder because the supply train was ambushed. We take fortresses, but cannot maintain tempo."

Don Luis gestures at the map's interior. "They have bases in the hill country—Ronda, Gaucín, perhaps others. They strike from there, fade back into terrain where heavy cavalry cannot follow. Infante Enrique's counter-raiding force attempted to hunt them in August." He glances at Don Rodrigo. "You know how that ended."

Don Rodrigo's jaw tightens. "Three thousand cavalry. Forty-seven dead, sixty-three wounded in a single ambush. The Infante himself took a lance wound. They knew we were coming, knew our route, had positions prepared. Our intelligence network in the interior is..." He stops. "Non-existent, Your Majesty. We're fighting blind."

Admiral Fadrique speaks up: "The coastal fortresses we've taken are supplied by sea now—it's the only reliable method. But that means our land supply lines to the eastern army, to Jaén, remain vulnerable. Every wagon train risks attack."

Don Luis meets your eyes. "Your Majesty, we can continue capturing fortresses. With the bombards and our numbers, Granada cannot stop us. But we're taking a fortress every three weeks instead of every week because of these raiders. And our casualties from ambushes now exceed our casualties from sieges."

He places both hands on the table. "We need a solution. Infante Enrique tried to hunt them with cavalry—failed. We've tried larger escorts—they simply hit different targets. We've tried occupying suspected base areas—they melt away and strike elsewhere."

The room falls silent. Maps, crosses marking ambush sites, the faces of tired commanders who've been grinding through this problem for months without answer.

Don Luis looks at you. "Your Majesty has come to take personal command. What are your orders?"

Your white armor catches the morning sun like a beacon as you ride before the assembled host. The white banner snaps in the breeze above you—that same banner carried at Alcalá la Real, symbol of the crusade's sacred purpose. Your father's sword gleams in your hand, the inscription Non Nobis Domine visible to those closest.

The speech rings across the formation. Six thousand men stand in absolute silence as your words carry—victories won, cowards hiding, the march into darkness to bring light.

When you draw the sword and cry "Non Nobis Domine!" the response is instantaneous and thunderous:

"NON NOBIS DOMINE!"

Six thousand voices roar it back. The words echo off Málaga's walls. Men raise weapons, beat sword on shield, stamp feet. The crossbowmen pound their pavises against the ground in rhythm. The cavalry horses dance and snort, catching their riders' energy.

"NON NOBIS DOMINE! NON NOBIS DOMINE!"

The chant becomes a battle cry, a prayer, a promise. On the walls, the watching garrison takes it up. Even the civilians join—washerwomen, merchants, children, everyone shouting the ancient crusader motto.

You turn your horse toward the northeast road and spur forward. The white banner streams behind you.

The army follows.

The vanguard cavalry moves first—two hundred horsemen forming protective screen. Then the scouts fan out ahead, already alert for raiders. The main column begins its march: crossbowmen in tight formation, infantry companies in marching order, the rumble of artillery wagons, thousands of boots and hooves churning dust from the coastal road.

Don Rodrigo rides near you, his face set with fierce determination. Captain Fernán and your royal guard form a protective ring. Pietro Calabrese shouts instructions in Italian-accented Castilian as his gun crews maneuver the bombards into the column.

The army stretches behind you like a great serpent—white banners, red crosses, the glint of steel and the forest of spears. Not raiders to be hunted through hills, but an army—disciplined, purposeful, terrible.

By noon, Málaga has vanished behind the coastal hills. The road climbs into rougher country—olive groves, scattered cork oak forests, rising terrain. This is the beginning of the hill country, the approaches to the mountains where Ronda sits.

The scouts report no contact yet. The raiders surely know you're coming by now—six thousand men cannot move invisibly—but they haven't shown themselves.

The march continues through afternoon heat. No incidents. Professional, steady progress. By evening, you've covered twelve miles—good time for an army with artillery.

Don Rodrigo selects the night's camp position: a hilltop with good sightlines, near water. The wagons are drawn into defensive circle. Crossbowmen deploy on the perimeter. Cavalry remains saddled and ready inside the laager. Camp fires are lit as sentries take their posts.

You stand on the hilltop as darkness falls, looking northeast toward where Ronda lies—still thirty miles away through increasingly hostile country. Somewhere out there, the raiders watch and plan.

The garrison soldier adds: "Water is problem in these hills, Your Majesty. Not like the Vega. Springs and streams, but must know where they are. The raiders, they know every water source. An army that does not find water..." He makes a throat-cutting gesture.

The March to Ronda

Days 1-3: September 24-26, 1431 - The Coastal Hills

The first three days establish the pattern. Your army moves at a steady eight miles per day—slower than pure infantry could march, but the artillery sets the pace. Pietro Calabrese's bombards rumble along, oxen straining at the yokes, gun crews walking alongside their precious weapons.

The raiders appear on the second day. Distant horsemen on ridgelines, watching. They never come close—your scouts report movement, but every time cavalry deploys to investigate, the raiders melt back into the hills. At night, you see their campfires in the distance, like wolves circling a campfire.

On the third day, they probe. A band of perhaps eighty riders sweeps toward your supply train as it negotiates a narrow valley. But Don Rodrigo's dispositions hold perfectly—two hundred crossbowmen deploy from the column in moments, pavise shields locked together. The raiders charge to within a hundred yards, then wheel away as crossbow bolts begin to fly. Three of their horses go down. They don't try again that day.

Day 4: September 27 - The First Village

The village of Alozaina sits astride the road, perhaps two hundred souls. Your scouts report they've seen the army coming—smoke signals went up yesterday from their watchtower.

You halt the army half a mile away and send emissaries: the converted knight and a translator, carrying a white flag. The terms are simple.

An hour later, the village elder walks out—an old man with a white beard, accompanied by the local imam. They kneel before you in your white armor. The elder's voice shakes: "Your Majesty, we submit. We are simple farmers. We want no war with Castile."

The oath is sworn. The village hands over three hundred sheep, forty cattle, two hundred bushels of grain. The imam and a dozen families choose to leave, heading northeast toward Granada with whatever they can carry. The rest remain, uncertain but alive.

You leave twenty men to secure the village and its supplies, then continue.

Days 5-6: September 28-29 - Deeper Into the Hills

The terrain grows rougher. Rocky valleys, olive groves clinging to steep hillsides, cork oak forests. The road narrows frequently. Your defensive protocols are tested repeatedly—each chokepoint negotiated with vanguard and rearguard deployed, crossbowmen ready.

The raiders attack the rearguard on Day 5 as it crosses a ford. One hundred fifty cavalry hit the tail of your column in a coordinated charge. But the sergeants have drilled this—crossbowmen form hedgehog, cavalry counter-charges from within the laager. The melee lasts ten minutes. You lose twelve men, but the raiders lose more. Bodies float downstream. They break off and don't return that day.

On Day 6, you secure a critical water source—a spring in a rocky valley. The raiders tried to foul it with dead animals the night before, but your scouts found and cleared it. The army drinks and fills water barrels. No one gets sick.

Day 7: September 30 - The Resistant Village

The village of Yunquera sees you coming and bars its gates. It's larger than Alozaina—perhaps four hundred people, stone walls around the center, a fortified tower. When your emissaries approach with terms, arrows fly from the walls. One translator takes a shaft through the shoulder.

Don Rodrigo looks at you. "Your Majesty?"

You give the order.

Pietro Calabrese positions two bombards. The first shots are ranging fire—stone balls smashing into the village walls, the thunder echoing through the valley. The fourth shot breaches the gate. The fifth collapses part of the tower.

Your infantry storms through. The fighting lasts an hour—brutal, close-quarters work in narrow streets. The defenders fight fanatically, but they're farmers and shepherds against veteran crusaders. When it ends, eighty villagers are dead, including the local garrison of perhaps twenty actual soldiers.

You order the survivors assembled in the square. Women, children, old men—perhaps two hundred fifty people, terrified and weeping. You give them the same choice: convert and submit, or leave with nothing.

Fifty choose baptism on the spot—mostly the young and pragmatic, calculating survival. The rest are marched out of the village with whatever they can carry and sent northeast. Their livestock, grain stores, and valuables are loaded onto your wagons.

Then you order the fortifications burned. The tower collapses in flames. The walls are pulled down where possible. When your army marches away the next morning, Yunquera is a smoking ruin that will never support raiders again.

The army's mood is grim but determined. The crossbowmen in particular are satisfied—the villagers shot first. This is war.

Days 8-9: October 1-2 - The Final Approach

Two more villages submit immediately. Word has spread about Yunquera. Elders come out waving white cloths before your army even stops. They hand over everything requested without negotiation. You accept their oaths, leave small garrisons, move on.

The raiders shadow you constantly now—you're deep in their territory, approaching Ronda. They probe every chokepoint, every ford, looking for weakness. Your rearguard is attacked three times on Day 8 alone. But the defensive discipline holds. Crossbowmen form, cavalry counters, raiders withdraw. You lose men—a steady trickle of five here, eight there, twelve at one particularly sharp ambush—but the army's cohesion never breaks.

On Day 9, your scouts bring unexpected news: they captured three raider scouts in an ambush. Under interrogation, the prisoners reveal Ronda's garrison is preparing for siege. The Sultan sent no reinforcements—Granada city is too weak after Alcalá la Real. Ronda stands alone.

Day 10: October 3, 1431 - Arrival at Ronda

The army crests a final ridge in the afternoon, and there it is.

Ronda.

The city sits on a massive limestone plateau, split by the Tajo gorge—a gash in the earth three hundred feet deep where the Guadalevín River has carved through stone over millennia. The fortress complex guards the northern approach where you stand, massive walls and towers built into the cliff edge. To the south and east, sheer drops to the gorge below. To the west, more cliffs and broken ground.

It's magnificent and terrible. One of Granada's strongest positions.

But you have six thousand men, six bombards, and the conquered coast at your back. Ronda's walls were built before gunpowder changed warfare forever.

Don Rodrigo rides up beside you, studying the fortress. "Your Majesty, we've arrived with minimal losses. Perhaps sixty-five men total—lighter than feared. The army is intact, supplied, and ready. The raiders are demoralized after failing to stop us."

Pietro Calabrese joins you, squinting at Ronda's walls with professional interest. "Is strong fortress, Majesty. But the walls... I see where we position guns. Two weeks, maybe three, we bring those down. They cannot stop the bombards."

Your army begins establishing camp on the high ground north of the city, out of bow range but close enough to intimidate. The defensive laager goes up with practiced efficiency—wagons circled, crossbowmen on perimeter, cavalry ready inside.

From Ronda's walls, you can see figures watching. Banners fly—Granada's green standards, defiant in the afternoon sun. The garrison knows you're here. They know what's coming.

Don Rodrigo awaits your orders. How do you wish to proceed with the siege?

Days 6-10: October 6-10, 1431 - Extending Control

Over the following days, your forces radiate outward from Ronda in coordinated sweeps.

October 6th:

Don Rodrigo dispatches cavalry columns—five hundred horsemen split into four groups, each targeting villages within a day's ride of Ronda. Infantry companies follow to establish garrisons in key locations.

The elder sees the Castilian banners, hears that Ronda has fallen without siege, and kneels within an hour. The oath is sworn. A twenty-man garrison is left. The cavalry moves on.

October 7th:

Three more villages submit. Word has spread impossibly fast—Ronda fallen, the king himself in residence, generous terms offered. The villages are calculating: resistance is suicide, submission offers survival and reasonable taxation.

But the fourth village—Gaucín, a fortified position on a hilltop twelve miles west—bars its gates. This is one of the secondary raider bases Muhammad mentioned. Perhaps two hundred fighters, families, supplies.

Your cavalry surrounds it but doesn't assault. The commander sends word: "Village fortified, garrison refuses terms. Request artillery support or permission to starve them out."

October 8th:

More importantly: The raiders are disappearing.

"Your Majesty," Don Rodrigo reports, "we've cut the head off the snake. Without Ronda's supplies, without Gaucín as a secondary base, the raiders cannot sustain operations. Some may still harass isolated targets, but coordinated ambushes of major convoys? That's finished. We've broken their operational capacity."

October 10th:

No attacks. No raiders. The convoy commander reports seeing distant horsemen—scouts, perhaps—but no one approached within bowshot. The roads are effectively open.

Muhammad ibn Rashid, working alongside Don Rodrigo, confirms: "Your Majesty, taking Ronda achieved what months of counter-raiding could not. The raiders operated from here, resupplied here, rested here. Without this fortress, they're just scattered bandits—dangerous to individuals but unable to threaten armies or major convoys."

He looks at the map. "The villages submitting cuts their intelligence network. They don't know where your forces are anymore, which routes are vulnerable. And the garrisons you've placed—even twenty men in a village means raiders can't rest there, can't requisition supplies."

Sheikh Ibrahim, who's been helping organize the transition, adds his assessment: "Your Majesty, the countryside is... relieved. These raiders were Muslims, yes, but they were also a plague—taking food, horses, sons for fighting. The villagers submitted to Your Majesty partly from fear, but partly because Castilian garrisons mean the raiders can no longer simply take what they want."

The Road to Toledo

Days 1-3: October 11-13, 1431 - Through the Hills

The first days are hard riding. Captain Fernán pushes the pace—thirty miles daily, which is punishing for cavalry with full kit. You climb out of Ronda's highlands into the rolling country beyond, following ancient Roman roads when you find them, cutting cross-country when the routes are clear.

The first night camps at a small village that submitted just days ago. The Castilian garrison there—twenty men—reports no raider activity. The roads are clear. Your escort rests briefly, then continues at dawn.

Day two brings you to Antequera, a mid-sized town firmly in Castilian hands. Fresh horses are available, but Captain Fernán judges your mounts can continue—no need to waste time. You press on after a brief meal, covering another thirty miles by sunset.

Day three, the terrain flattens as you approach the Guadalquivir valley. This is unquestionably Castilian territory now—farms, villages flying Christian banners, churches visible in every settlement. The war feels distant. Your escort relaxes slightly, though discipline remains tight.

Day 4: October 14 - The Complication

Morning of the fourth day, you're making excellent time. The road to Córdoba stretches ahead, clear and well-maintained. Captain Fernán estimates you'll reach the city by afternoon, possibly press through to cut another day off the journey.

Then, around midday, you reach the Guadalquivir River crossing at a ford that should be simple.

It's not.

Three days of unexpected rain in the mountains upstream—news you hadn't heard—has turned the normally placid crossing into a swift, muddy torrent. The water runs waist-deep and fast, full of debris. One of your scouts tests the ford and his horse nearly loses footing on the treacherous bottom.

Captain Fernán rides up beside you, frowning at the river. "Your Majesty, this is... problematic. We could try the ford anyway—lose maybe two or three horses, risk men being swept downstream. Or..." He points upriver. "There's a bridge at Córdoba proper, about eight miles that way. But that adds most of a day to reach it and cross."

One of your sergeants adds: "Could wait for the water to drop, Your Majesty. Maybe by tomorrow afternoon it'll be passable. But that's a full day lost."

The hundred cavalry wait behind you, horses stamping, men looking at the swollen river with professional wariness. It's not life-threatening—you could order the crossing and probably lose only horses, not men. But it's dangerous and uncertain.

You choose the prudent option: detour to Córdoba's bridge.

The eight-mile ride upriver eats the afternoon. You reach Córdoba's great Roman bridge as the sun sets—a magnificent piece of ancient engineering spanning the Guadalquivir with sixteen arches. Your escort crosses without incident, the horses' hooves echoing on two-thousand-year-old stone.

Córdoba offers to host you for the night—the city's governor has quarters prepared—but you decline. You've already lost hours; stopping now means losing the entire day's progress. Instead, you push through the city and continue north in gathering darkness for another two hours before making camp.

Day four ends having covered only about twenty miles instead of the planned thirty. One day lost to a river you couldn't have predicted.

Days 5-7: October 15-17 - The Final Push

The remaining days are hard, grinding travel. Captain Fernán pushes to make up lost time—long days in the saddle, brief rest stops, pressing through until darkness forces halt. The horses are showing strain; three go lame and must be left at villages with promises to retrieve them later. The men are exhausted but determined.

Day five: Thirty-five miles, passing through La Mancha's open plains.

Day six: Another thirty-five miles, the escort now visibly worn. You enter Castile's heartland—familiar territory, completely secure, churches and castles everywhere.

Day seven: The final push to Toledo. You spot the city's unmistakable silhouette in the late afternoon—the Alcázar rising above the Tagus River, the cathedral's tower, medieval walls cascading down the hillside. One of Castile's greatest cities, and more importantly: Isabel is here.

Your escort is battered—horses blown, men swaying in saddles from exhaustion, armor dusty and travel-stained. But you've made it. Seven days from Ronda to Toledo instead of the planned six. Not disastrous, but the delay reminds you that even with secure roads, distance and nature still impose their will.

Evening - October 17th, 1431 - Toledo

The city gates open as your white armor is recognized. Word spreads instantly: the king has returned. You ride through streets filling with citizens—merchants, artisans, nobles, all cheering the conquering hero. News of Ronda's fall has preceded you.

The Alcázar looms ahead. As you enter the courtyard, you see figures rushing to the entrance. Servants, guards, courtiers—and there, emerging into the fading sunlight, moving as quickly as a woman six months pregnant can move:

Isabel.

She stops at the top of the steps, one hand on her swollen belly, the other clutching the carved Virgin Mary figure you gave her in August. Her face—plain by courtly standards but radiant to you—shows relief, joy, and the accumulated fear of two months' separation finally released.

She doesn't wait for you to dismount. She starts down the steps, and Dona Beatriz has to hurry to support her arm. By the time you've swung down from your horse, Isabel has reached you, propriety abandoned, throwing her arms around you despite the dusty armor and watching court.

"Thank God," she whispers against your chest. "Thank God you're home."

Behind her, the royal household has assembled. Álvaro de Luna—your Constable—watches with satisfaction. Other nobles, courtiers, servants. But for this moment, there's only Isabel, pregnant and relieved, holding you like she'll never let go.

She stops herself, drawing a shaking breath. "I'm sorry. You're home now. That's what matters." She glances at the assembled courtiers watching this reunion, then back to you. Behind her, Don Álvaro de Luna bows. "Your Majesty, welcome home. The court has much to discuss, but it can wait until morning. Tonight should be for your reunion with the Queen."

The household staff is already moving—servants rushing to prepare chambers, calling for hot water and food, the machinery of royal hospitality springing into action.

Isabel still holds your arm, looking up at you with exhausted relief. "Please, Juan. I've missed you terribly. Can we just... talk? Just us?"

Reunion in Toledo

Isabel nods eagerly, relief flooding her face. She keeps her hand on your arm as you walk together into the Alcázar, the household parting before you. Dona Beatriz follows at a discreet distance, while Captain Fernán disperses your exhausted escort to quarters and stables.

Your chambers—the royal apartments overlooking the Tagus—have been kept ready. As you enter, servants are already lighting lamps against the gathering dusk. The familiar Portuguese chapel corner Isabel established catches your eye: the carved Virgin Mary in place of honor, fresh flowers, well-used prayer cushions.

"Your Majesty, let me help with that armor," a squire says, already moving to unbuckle your breastplate. The process is familiar—straps loosened, plates removed piece by piece, the weight lifting from shoulders and back after seven days of hard riding. Your gambeson beneath is sweat-stained and road-dusty.

Isabel watches from a chair, one hand resting on her belly, the other fidgeting with her skirts. She's trying not to hover, but her eyes follow your every movement.

A basin of warm water appears. You wash face, hands, neck—the grime of travel sluicing away. A clean shirt is produced. The relief of being out of armor after days of travel is profound.

"Your beer, Your Majesty." A servant presents a pewter tankard, condensation beading on the metal. The beer is cold from the cellar, bitter and refreshing. You drink deeply.

Isabel dismisses the servants with a gesture. "Leave us, please. I'll call if we need anything." Even Dona Beatriz withdraws, though she leaves the door slightly ajar for propriety's sake.

Alone now—or as alone as royalty ever gets—Isabel rises and comes to you. She's moving more slowly, carefully, one hand always steadying her belly. She reaches up to touch your face, as if confirming you're real.

"You look tired," she says softly. "Thinner, I think. Have you been eating properly?" The wifely concern breaks through her formal composure. Then: "Tell me everything. What happened at Ronda? The messenger said you negotiated surrender, that you rode out alone to meet their commander. Juan..." Her voice wavers. "You promised to come back to us."

She guides you to sit, then carefully lowers herself into the chair beside you, angling it so she can see your face. "Start from the beginning. Tell me what happened after you left Jaén in September."

What do you tell her?

I tell her everything and explain that sometimes I have to place my fate in God's hands. That trusting in God's plan ultimately saves lives. That if I had not done so, there would have been a siege with many casualties and plunder. That I as a king have to show myself and in doing so, I achieve the grace and mercy Isabel has been praying for so fiercely.

Juan is explaining to Isabel his reasoning for the risks he took - riding out personally to negotiate, trusting God's plan, and how this ultimately saved lives and led to a peaceful surrender. "Juan..." she breathes, but lets you continue.

"I understand," she says finally, voice thick with emotion. "I do, Juan. When you put it that way—that your faith, your willingness to trust God completely, saved all those lives..." She touches the Virgin Mary figure hanging at her neck. "That's what I've been praying for. Mercy. A way to end this war without endless slaughter."

She wipes at her eyes. "And God answered. Through you. Through your courage to stand there, alone and vulnerable, trusting that He would protect you." A slight smile. "You showed them Christ's love, in a way. Even in conquest, you offered them dignity, terms they could accept."

"The baby moves and I think—what if their father never comes home? What if I have to tell this child about their brave father who died before they were born?"

She looks at you, torn between pride and fear. "I know you're a king. I know you must lead, must show yourself, must trust in God's plan. And I'm so proud of what you accomplished—truly, Juan. Ronda without a siege is... it's miraculous."

Her grip tightens on your hand. "But you're also a husband. And soon you'll be a father. And I need you to come home. Not just for the kingdom—for us." Tears spill over now. "I know that's selfish. I know God calls you to do great things. But Juan, I can't lose you. I can't."

She's crying openly now, the accumulated stress and fear of two months pouring out. "Promise me—promise me you'll be careful. That you won't take unnecessary risks. That you'll remember you have a wife and child who need you." She looks up at you, vulnerable and pleading. "Please."

I pull her close and hold her tight for a long moment. You will never lose me Isabel.
